linkTarget.anchoringText: The Williston basin, one of the major resources of oil and gas in the United States, covers more than 300,000 square miles in area and includes Saskatchewan and Manitoba in Canada and Montana and South Dakota in US (Fig. 1). The Bakken formation and Three Forks formation, located in the subsurface of the Williston basin, are the two the main produced formations. The Bakken formation comprises three members: the upper shale, the middle dolomite, and the lower shale.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: a) Map of Williston basin. b) Major target formations (Smith 2012).

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Map of Williston basin. b) Major target formations (Smith 2012).

linkTarget.bib:
Smith, 2012
T. Smith
2012. From Trickle to Gusher: The Bakken Oil Story . p>https://www.geoexpro.com/articles/2012/05/from-trickle-to-gusher-the-bakken-oil-story (accessed 26 June 2018).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The maximum thickness of the Bakken formation is about 140 ft, whereas for Three Forks formation, maximum thickness is about 270 ft (Tran et al. 2011). The increased activity since 2007 is the result of advances in horizontal drilling and multistage hydraulic fracturing. Due to the downturn of the oil industry, the total rig count dropped to about 25 in May 2016, as shown in Fig. 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Rig count and monthly oil production (EIA, May 2018).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Rig count and monthly oil production (EIA, May 2018).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Bakken petroleum system lies within the oil window of the vast Williston Basin. As of today, numerous operators are actively developing the Bakken and Three Forks formations, pursuing a variety of drilling and completion strategies. Fig. 3 shows the production history of Bakken wells up to 2013. Before 2000, most Bakken wells had marginal economic success partially due to extremely low matrix permeability (0.0001 to 0.01 md) as well as failed attempts to exploit many localized natural factures with a vertical well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Historical daily oil production rate and number of active producing wells (including Bakken, Sanish, Three Forks, and Bakken/Three Forks pools) (Data Source: NDIC Oil and Gas Division 2013) (Kumar et al. 2013).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Historical daily oil production rate and number of active producing wells (including Bakken, Sanish, Three Forks, and Bakken/Three Forks pools) (Data Source: NDIC Oil and Gas Division 2013) (Kumar et al. 2013).

linkTarget.bib:
Kumar et al., 2013
S. Kumar , T. Hoffman , and M. Prasad
2013. Upper and Lower Bakken Shale Production Contribution to the Middle Bakken Reservoir. Presented at the Unconventional Resources Technology Conference, Denver, Colorado, USA, 12–14 August . URTEC-1581459-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Understanding the production characteristics of the Bakken play is the key to success for the operators in the area. The recovery mechanism can be identified from a production performance plot. Fig. 4 plots gas-oil ratio (GOR) versus time for three fundamental primary recovery mechanisms. Fluid expansion drive is the expected recovery method in the Middle Bakken reservoir (O'Brien et al. 2012).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Well GOR trends of different primary recovery mechanisms.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well GOR trends of different primary recovery mechanisms.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Kumar et al. (2013) targeted some performance anomalies in the GOR trends for several fields in the Bakken play and proposed the possibility of production contribution from Upper and Lower Bakken shale to the Middle Bakken reservoir. Fig. 5 shows cumulative GOR versus cumulative oil production for all the wells from the Elkhorn Ranch field in North Dakota.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative GOR with respective cumulative oil production for the Elkhorn Ranch field from the North Dakota Bakken play (data source: NDIC Oil and Gas Division 2013) (Kumar et al., 2013).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative GOR with respective cumulative oil production for the Elkhorn Ranch field from the North Dakota Bakken play (data source: NDIC Oil and Gas Division 2013) (Kumar et al., 2013).

linkTarget.bib:
Kumar et al., 2013

2013. Upper and Lower Bakken Shale Production Contribution to the Middle Bakken Reservoir. Presented at the Unconventional Resources Technology Conference, Denver, Colorado, USA, 12–14 August . URTEC-1581459-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Three Forks formation is another important part of the Bakken petroleum system. Source rock maturity is considered a primary control on the extent of Three Forks production across the basin (Sonnenberg 2015). Poor production exists outside the maturity boundary. The level of source rock maturity can be determined via source rock analysis or resistivity of shales. Fig. 6 illustrates areas of source rock maturity based on resistivity measurements in the Upper and Lower Bakken shales. Three Forks production appears to coincide with areas of high resistivity, which suggests good source rock quality.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Initial production (IP) map for Three Forks and Bakken structure with 100 ohm-m resistivity contour line overlaid as indicator for source rock maturity of Upper and Lower Bakken shales (Sonnenberg 2015).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Initial production (IP) map for Three Forks and Bakken structure with 100 ohm-m resistivity contour line overlaid as indicator for source rock maturity of Upper and Lower Bakken shales (Sonnenberg 2015).

linkTarget.bib:
Sonnenberg, 2015
S. Sonnenberg
2015. Keys to Production, Three Forks Formation, Williston Basin. Presented at the Unconventional Resources Technology Conference, San Antonio, Texas, USA, 20–22 July . SPE-178510-MS. https://doi.org/10.2118/178510-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: An areal analysis in Fig. 7 of historical water production also revealed that the southern Nesson anticline and areas east of the Nesson anticline show the highest oil to water ratio. The warm colors indicate wells that produce more oil than water.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Three Forks production map (oil cut) for the first three months (Sonnenberg 2015).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Three Forks production map (oil cut) for the first three months (Sonnenberg 2015).

linkTarget.bib:
Sonnenberg, 2015
S. Sonnenberg
2015. Keys to Production, Three Forks Formation, Williston Basin. Presented at the Unconventional Resources Technology Conference, San Antonio, Texas, USA, 20–22 July . SPE-178510-MS. https://doi.org/10.2118/178510-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Lateral length and completion strategy are two other parameters that the operators have experimented with. Fig. 8a shows that in the Bakken, lateral length over the past decade has ranged from 1,000 to more than 10,000 ft. As longer laterals are drilled in the Bakken, operators have started to shift from an openhole completion using ball-activated sliding sleeves (OHSS) to cemented-casing plug-and-perforation (CCPP) demonstrated by Fig. 8b. This is mainly driven by the need for greater flexibility in increasingly longer laterals with clusters close together, and therefore greater wellbore stability must be considered (Lu et al. 2018a).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Factors controlling production in major shale plays in North America. (a) Average lateral length. (b) Evolution of completion strategy employed in horizontal shale wells (Data Source: IHS Enerdeq) (Lu 2018).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Factors controlling production in major shale plays in North America. (a) Average lateral length. (b) Evolution of completion strategy employed in horizontal shale wells (Data Source: IHS Enerdeq) (Lu 2018).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Factors controlling production in major shale plays in North America. (a) Average lateral length.
Evolution of completion strategy employed in horizontal shale wells (Data Source: IHS Enerdeq) (Lu 2018).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Artificial lift results per production stage are combined with the generic decline curve on Fig. 9. This gives us a starting point on how to design an artificial lift strategy that covers the different stages on production. Artificial lift systems for the second stage or initial artificial lift installation are designed according to the expected decline and then modeled using nodal analysis (Fig. 10) to determine the effective drawdown and expected production rate from each system. To calculate production during the life of the well, input values are taken from the generated LUT on a timestep basis of one value per month.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Production stages with recommended artificial lift system.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production stages with recommended artificial lift system.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Artificial lift results per production stage are combined with the generic decline curve on Fig. 9. This gives us a starting point on how to design an artificial lift strategy that covers the different stages on production. Artificial lift systems for the second stage or initial artificial lift installation are designed according to the expected decline and then modeled using nodal analysis (Fig. 10) to determine the effective drawdown and expected production rate from each system. To calculate production during the life of the well, input values are taken from the generated LUT on a timestep basis of one value per month.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Nodal analysis models per artificial lift system designs.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Nodal analysis models per artificial lift system designs.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using nodal analysis, natural flow, ESP, and JP are modeled. It is important to consider that during production, inflow and outflow, the main components of nodal analysis, change over time. Inflow changes in the reservoir pressure and productivity index occur over time, and those changes are fed to the model using the generated LUT. In the same way, outflow is governed by the type of artificial lift system installed, changes in PVT properties, and tubinghead pressure. This case study considers constant water cut and GOR, making outflow fully governed by the specific artificial lift system and tubinghead pressure. The combined changes in inflow and outflow over time can be seen in Fig. 11.
Cumulative liquid production for each simulation case is displayed on Fig. 12. The results are summarized below:

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Production comparison of different artificial lift strategies.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production comparison of different artificial lift strategies.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For short-term estimation, the ESP and JP installation after 3 months of natural flow will increase the cumulative liquid production due to the system's ability to increase drawdown. Details on the simulation are shown on Fig. 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Production comparison for initial simulation length of 1 year.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production comparison for initial simulation length of 1 year.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Two additional water cut cases are considered, 26% and 50%. A disposal water cost is imposed to the water production making the high water cut case less attractive for all the simulated scenarios. NPVs are calculated and displayed on Fig. 13 and Fig. 14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Economic comparison at 50% water cut by different artificial lift strategies.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Economic comparison at 50% water cut by different artificial lift strategies.
